problem_text:
Let N be a nilpotent subgroup of a finite simple group G. Is it true that there exists a subgroup N1 conjugate to N such that N ∩ N1 = 1?
The answer is known to be affirmative if N is a p-group. Comment of 2013: an affirmative answer for alternating groups is obtained in (R. K. Kurmazov, Siberian Math. J., 54, no. 1 (2013), 73–77).
E. P. Vdovin
answer: Yes it is true; moreover, for any two nilpotent subgroups H, K of a (non-abelian) finite simple group G there is g ∈ G such that H ∩ K^g = 1 (T. C. Burness, H. Y. Huang, Preprint, 2025, https://arxiv.org/abs/2508.03479).
